content.webTitle: Geraint Thomas eager to enjoy Tour of Britain after whirlwind month

fields.headline: Geraint Thomas eager to enjoy Tour of Britain after whirlwind month
fields.bodyText: Geraint Thomas is apparently on the point of signing a new contract with Team Sky but is unlikely to take any decision over whether or not he claims team leadership in defending his Tour de France title until November at the earliest, the Welshman said as he prepared to take on the eight-day Tour of Britain, which will probably be his final challenge of the season. “I haven’t signed with Sky yet but we are pretty close, I’m happy in the team and it has worked well for me I think,” he said. “I’m not thinking about next year too much. Come November we will sit down and see the routes for the different races, the Giro and Tour, make a plan and go from there.” The Tour winner said he did not anticipate any issues with the four-times winner Chris Froome, who finished third in this year’s race, and will be his teammate again if he signs a new deal with Sky. “It worked well for us this year, we were honest with each other and there was always a good atmosphere.” Thomas added that he has felt determined to take full advantage of the time after his Tour win rather than begin making concrete plans for the future. “There is always another race around the corner, so I wanted to enjoy it and make the most of it. I wanted to live in the moment and go from there when the time comes. “Since the Tour I’ve had a few nights out, I went to the Emirates for an Arsenal game, there was the homecoming in Cardiff, a couple of criterium, but a lot of late nights and early mornings. “There have been some interviews, getting stitched up over helmets” – a reference to an interview in the Sunday Times when he stated he was in favour of cycle helmets being made compulsory. “It’s been a whirlwind. There has been no time to enjoy it and chill out.” Thomas spent part of Saturday at the Maindy track in Cardiff, where he began racing, and he was surprised by the reception. “There were 170 kids there or something, there were a lot of things to sign.” He expects Sunday’s stage across south Wales from Pembry to Newport – where the national indoor velodrome is about to be named in his honour – to be “insane”. “I want to enjoy it, racing on home roads isn’t something we get to do very often. I want to lap it up. Performance-wise I’m not going to set the world alight. I’ve not done much for the last month. “I’ve been here there and everywhere because it’s not every day that you win the Tour. I’m knackered, I’ve been so busy since the Tour that I’ve not really recovered.” Thomas and Froome conceded that in the next few days they are likely to play second fiddle to their Dutch teammate Wout Poels, given that both feel they are well off their best form. Froome added that his decision to race in Britain rather than defend his title at the Vuelta a España was largely due to the arrival of his and his wife’s second child shortly after the Tour. “It’s a good time to step back from Grand Tours and gather myself a bit,” he said. The two Team Sky leaders have been shortlisted for the world road race championships in Innsbruck at the end of the month, but Thomas as good as said here that he will not race, while Froome will assess his form after this week, but is also unlikely to ride, although the course would suit his climbing skills well. “I think I have pushed the envelope as far as I can this season,” said Froome, who began racing earlier than usual in order to be in his best form for the Giro d’Italia in mid-May. “I took a break after the Tour, I’ve been training well but the worlds will be a brutal race.” Before the Giro, Froome tackled the world championships course in Innsbruck during the Tour of the Alps and was suitably impressed. “There is over 5,000 metres of climbing, so unless you are in absolutely top condition it’s not a race where you can sit in the wheels. It will show exactly what form you are in.” The consensus is that this Tour of Britain will be decided on Thursday and Friday when the race takes in the climb of Whinlatter Pass in the Lake District three times, with a short, tough team-time trial on the Thursday. Whatever happens there, the pair have moved on a long way since the last time they teamed up at this race, in 2009 for the Barloworld squad, when the most significant thing Thomas could remember was that the race went through the Somerset town of Frome, to the team’s great amusement.
